snippet: Through forced sterilizations and abortions, the killing of infants and the sale of children, the decades-old policy touched families across China.

byline.contributor: Chris Buckley contributed reporting. Mia Li and Vanessa Piao contributed research.

abstract: Deng Jiyuan, whose wife Feng Jianmei became national symbol of abuses of Chinese government's rigid limits on family size, reflects on decision to shift away from one-child rule to two-child policy; local officials forced Feng into induced labor seven months into her pregnancy, resulting in stillborn child; what Feng suffered is in many ways typical of what others have experienced under one-child policy.
lead_paragraph: Through forced sterilizations and abortions, the killing of infants and the sale of children, the decades-old policy touched families across China.

headline.print_headline: China’s Longtime One-Child Rule Is Gone, but Trauma Lingers
headline.main: One-Child Rule Is Gone in China, but Trauma Lingers for Many
